DATE: [**3060-1-8**] 3:40 PM
     CHEST (PORTABLE AP); -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 8574**]
     Reason: please eval for CHF/PNA                                     
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
           75 year old man with hypotension and recent V tach.                        
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please eval for CHF/PNA                                                         
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  75-year-old male with hypertension and recent V-TACH.  Evaluate
     for CHF or pneumonia.
     
     COMPARISONS:  Comparison is made to [**3059-12-21**].
     
     TECHNIQUE:  AP semi-upright single view of the chest.
     
     FINDINGS:  There is a left chest wall AICD biventricular pacer with leads in
     unchanged position.  There is again noted cardiomegaly.  The heart size is
     stable when compared to prior study.  There is interval increase in opacity
     involving the entire right lung.  There are also more patchy opacities
     involving the left mid and lower lung zones. There appears to be a left
     pleural effusion. These findings could represent asymmetric pulmonary edema
     Vs. an infectious process involving the right lung.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1.  Findings are most consistent with asymmetric pulmonary edema. However,
     superimposed infection cannot be excluded.
     2.  Left pleural effusion.
     3.  Stable cardiomegaly.

     CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 12264**]

     ______________________________________________________________________________

     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      eval for position of SVC, ETT, OG tube.
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  65 year old man with severe CHF, intubated for respiratory
     distress s/p right IJ placement, ETT placement.
     
     A single AP portable radiograph of the chest dated [**2977-1-16**] compared with prior
     AP portable on [**2977-1-16**] at 1637.
     
     FINDINGS:  There is stable appearance of the cardiomediastinal and hilar
     contours.  There has been significant interval improvement in the appearance
     of the bilateral patchy and confluent air space opacities.  There are no
     pleural effusions however, the extreme left costophrenic angle has been
     excluded from the study.  A dual lead ICD is seen with tips in the right
     atrium and right ventricle.  An ETT tip is seen approximately 5 cm above the
     carina.  A right-sided central venous catheter is seen with its tip in the
     upper SVC.  A NGT is seen with its tip in the proximal stomach and sideport at
     the GE junction.  Soft tissue and osseous structures are unremarkable.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Interval improvement in the appearance of the CHF.
     2)  Sideport of NGT at GE junction, recommend advancement by [**2-9**] inches.
     3)  All other lines and tubes in satisfactory positioning.

DATE: [**3452-7-19**] 6:27 PM
     CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 13554**]
     Reason: pna, ett placement                                          
     Admitting Diagnosis: ST ELEVATION MI; RESPIRATORY FAILURE\CATH
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      63 year old man with pna s/p intubation and transfer from osh                   
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pna, ett placement                                                              
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     DATE OF EXAM:  [**3452-7-19**].
     
     INDICATIONS:  Status post intubation and transfer from outside hospital for
     pneumonia.
     
     PORTABLE AP CHEST:  Comparison is made to digitized images from an outside
     hospital.  The endotracheal tube is in satisfactory position several
     centimeters above the carina.  The cardiac size is at the upper limits of
     normal.  There are bilateral pulmonary parenchymal opacities, which initially
     began in the right lower lobe, and subsequently involved the whole right lung
     and the central portion of the left lung.  On the current study, there is a
     clearing of the right lower lobe opacity, but increased opacity in both upper
     lobes.  While pneumonia is on the differential diagnosis, the rapid change in
     appearance is likely due to aspiration.  There is collapse/consolidation of
     the left lower lobe.
     
     IMPRESSION: Bilateral parenchymal opacities consistent with pneumonia. Given
     the rapid change on multiple serial films, aspiration is in the differential
     diagnosis.

     AP CHEST RADIOGRAPH:  There is an ET tube, with the tip positioned in the
     lower trachea, approximately 1.5 cm above the carina.  The heart and

     vasculature, which may reflect low lung volumes.  No pleural effusion or
     pneumothorax is seen.  The osseous structures are within normal limits, no
     fractures are identified.  There is a large amount of air within the stomach.
     
     AP PELVIS RADIOGRAPH:  Overlying structures on the trauma board obscure
     underlying detail.  The osseous structures are normal in appearance.  There is
     no evidence of fracture.  Hip joints are normal.  The sacroiliac joints and
     pubic symphysis are not widened.  The bowel gas pattern is within normal
     limits.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1.  The ET tube tip is positioned in the lower trachea, approximately 1.5 cm
     above the carina.  Withdrawal by 2-3 cm should be considered.
     2.  There is a large amount of air within the stomach.

DATE: [**2804-3-19**] 10:05 PM
     CHEST (PA & LAT)                                                Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 13256**]
     Reason: r/o PNA                                                     
     Admitting Diagnosis: T1 FRACTURE
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      88 year old man with PNA                                                        
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      r/o PNA                                                                         
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  Pneumonia, rule out pneumonia.
     
     CHEST, TWO VIEWS.
     
     There is a large (7.5 cm) opacity in the left lower lobe posteriorly.  It
     abuts the posterior chest wall and may obscure a portion of the posterior
     diaphragm.  No gross effusion is identified.  Heart size is at the upper
     limits of normal.  No CHF, other focal opacity, or effusion is identified. The
     hilar and mediastinal silhouette is within normal limits for age.
     
     Narrowing of the acromiohumeral distance in the right shoulder is compatible
     with a chronic complete rotator cuff tear. 
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     Focal opacity in the left lower lobe posteriorly.  In appropriate clinical
     setting, this could represent an atypical presentation of pneumonia. However,
     given the relatively discrete rounded appearance on the frontal view, the
     possibility of a focal lung mass should be considered.  As a result, short-
     term followup to resolution or, alternatively, a chest CT is recommended for
     further assessment.  Rounded atelectasis is considered much less likely given
     the absence of diffuse pleural abnormalities.

      evaluate for infiltrate, edema                                                  
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female with sepsis and C. diff, now with tachypnea.
     
     PORTABLE SEMI-UPRIGHT CHEST RADIOGRAPH:  Comparison made to multiple prior
     chest radiographs dating back to [**2916-2-16**].  The patient is markedly rotated,
     limiting evaluation. Allowing for rotational differences, cardiomediastinal
     contours are unchanged since [**2916-3-10**].  Left-sided PICC line terminates with
     its tip overlying the distal SVC.  Moderate layering left-sided pleural
     effusion has increased. Small right pleural effusion has also increased in
     size. Retrocardiac opacity is also increased, and although positional
     differences may account for some of the increased opacity, this area remains
     suspicious for an area of focal consolidation.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1.  Moderate sized layering left pleural effusion, and small right pleural
     effusion, both increased from [**2916-3-10**].
     2.  Increase in size and density of retrocardiac opacity, which may be
     related to technical differences, but this area remains suspicious for
     underlying consolidation or atelectasis.
